entry.title: Why COVID-19 is not the world‚Äôs ‚Äògreat leveller‚Äô | All Hail The Lockdown

media:group.media:title: Why COVID-19 is not the world‚Äôs ‚Äògreat leveller‚Äô | All Hail The Lockdown
media:group.media:description:
‚ÄòExpose It‚Äô - Privilege & Poverty During A Crisis
In episode 4 of #AllHailTheLockdown Ali Rae speaks with Indian activists Arundhati Roy and Bezwada Wilson about how "the world's biggest lockdown" on the subcontinent was made much worse because of pre-existing inequalities. Ali also speaks with social epidemiologist Manuel Franco and feminist historian Josefina Martinez in Spain to explore the ways geographic and gender inequity impacted the coronavirus pandemic.
#AllHailTheLockdown is a 5 part series exploring the complexities of our global response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

entry.title: ‚ÄòLose-lose‚Äô: Australia slams reported China coal import curbs

media:group.media:title: ‚ÄòLose-lose‚Äô: Australia slams reported China coal import curbs
media:group.media:description:
China‚Äôs state media appears to have confirmed that Beijing has approved cuts to Australian coal imports, in a move which is likely to cost the Australian economy billions of dollars. The Global Times newspaper reported that power plants have been granted approval to import coal without clearance from most countries ‚Äúexcept Australia‚Äù. Australia and China's trade dispute has been getting worse as diplomatic ties between the two fray.
Al Jazeera‚Äôs Nicola Gage reports from Sydney, Australia.

entry.title: Solar eclipse turns skies dark over Chile and Argentina

media:group.media:title: Solar eclipse turns skies dark over Chile and Argentina
media:group.media:description:
Heads turned skywards in South America to view this year's only total solar eclipse. For around two minutes, spectators in Argentina and Chile cheered as the clouds cleared to unveil the rare spectacle. The next one will not occur until 2024.
Al Jazeera‚Äôs Lucia Newman reports from Santiago, Chile.

entry.title: S Korea bans flying anti-N Korea leaflets across border

media:group.media:title: S Korea bans flying anti-N Korea leaflets across border
media:group.media:description:
South Korea‚Äôs National Assembly has passed a controversial law making it illegal to launch propaganda material into North Korea, in a bid to revive denuclearisation talks. Under this new law, offenders will now face up to three years in prison and thousands of dollars in fines. But defectors and activists say the law violates their right to free speech.
Al Jazeera‚Äôs Rob McBride reports from Seoul, South Korea.

entry.title: UK identifies new coronavirus variant; London on toughest curbs

media:group.media:title: UK identifies new coronavirus variant; London on toughest curbs
media:group.media:description:
Countries around Europe are again tightening restrictions as coronavirus infection rates rising during the holiday season. In the United Kingdom, the government says a new variant of the novel coronavirus which it has identified could be linked to the rapid rise in cases. London and some surrounding areas are due to be placed on the highest level of COVID-19 restrictions. The Netherlands and Germany have announced new nationwide lockdowns while Italy is debating whether to put in place tougher measures. Workers in Paris have protested against the curbs.
Al Jazeera's Jonah Hull reports from London, the UK.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#Coronavirus #Coronavirus2Wave #Tier3London

entry.title: ‚ÄòTerrorist attack‚Äô strikes oil tanker at Saudi port in Jeddah

media:group.media:title: ‚ÄòTerrorist attack‚Äô strikes oil tanker at Saudi port in Jeddah
media:group.media:description:
A port in Saudi Arabia has reopened hours after an oil tanker was hit by a boat laden with explosives. The Singapore-flagged BW Rhine was docked in Jeddah's port, Its owner Hafnia says all 22 sailors on board escaped unhurt. No group has yet said it was behind Monday's blast, which Saudi Arabia has described as a ‚Äúterrorist attack‚Äù.
Al Jazeera‚Äôs Alexi O'Brien reports.

entry.title: US deaths from COVID-19 pass 300,000 as vaccine rolls out

media:group.media:title: US deaths from COVID-19 pass 300,000 as vaccine rolls out
media:group.media:description:
On the same day as the largest vaccination campaign against the coronavirus in the United States began, COVID-19 deaths crossed the 300,000 mark. Medical workers were among the first to be immunised with the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine and a separate jab from Moderna is due to be approved next week. But polls suggest more than half of Americans do not trust the vaccine.
Al Jazeera‚Äôs Patty Culhane reports from Washington, DC, the US.

#Trump #COVID19Vaccine #Pfizer

entry.title: Electoral College officially confirms Biden presidential victory

media:group.media:title: Electoral College officially confirms Biden presidential victory
media:group.media:description:
US President-elect Joe Biden has told Americans that democracy has "prevailed," after the Electoral College formally validated his victory in the November presidential election. Its members gave Biden 306 votes to President Donald Trump‚Äôs 232 votes. Despite that, Trump still sent out multiple tweets about election fraud.
Al Jazeera‚Äôs Shihab Rattansi reports from Wilmington, Delaware, the US.

#USelection2020 #BidenHarris2020 #PresidentElectJoe

entry.title: Is war an inescapable part of who we are? | The Stream

media:group.media:title: Is war an inescapable part of who we are? | The Stream
media:group.media:description:
Historian Margaret MacMillan's latest book 'War: How Conflict Shaped Us' is a provoking and broad meditation on the nature of war, how it impacts human societies and even how it has driven innovation and improved the standing of women.
MacMillan, Professor of History at the University of Toronto and emeritus Professor of International History at the University of Oxford, believes that we don't study war enough or talk about it enough - and that our short memories can render us blind to threats of conflict.
In this episode of The Stream, we meet MacMillan to discuss her new book and to consider the questions raised by her work as a historian of the 20th century.
Join the conversation: TWITTER: https://twitter.com/AJStream FACEBOOK: http://www.facebook.com/AJStream Subscribe to our channel http://bit.ly/AJSubscribe
#aljazeeraenglish #ajstream #war #news

entry.title: üåç Can young climate activists save Africa? | The Stream

media:group.media:title: üåç Can young climate activists save Africa? | The Stream
media:group.media:description:
A new generation of climate justice activists has come of age in the¬†five years since¬†196 countries agreed to sign the Paris Agreement. And with Africa facing disproportionate impacts¬†of climate change, young people across the continent are now leading the fight for urgent and effective action.
Young activists from countries including Uganda, Nigeria, South Africa and Kenya are demanding that domestic, regional and global decision-makers take climate change more seriously, not least because younger generations will be the inheritors of a world profoundly altered by global heating. The impact of climate change is already particularly acute in Africa, with people across the continent already facing extreme weather conditions ranging from floods to prolonged drought ‚Äì affecting crop yields, provoking tensions over access to land, and driving migration.
With populations across sub-Saharan Africa among the¬†youngest in the world, youth campaigners are now¬†encouraging other people¬†to act directly within their own communities and change the conversation on climate action and justice. But with Africa only producing between 2 and 3 percent of global carbon dioxide emissions, young campaigners across the continent are also trying to convince world leaders ‚Äì including those representing the worst polluters on Earth - to act more decisively and give Africa a fighting chance.
Three climate activists join The Stream to discuss how they are working to ensure a just and stable future for Africa.
Join the conversation: TWITTER: https://twitter.com/AJStream FACEBOOK: http://www.facebook.com/AJStream Subscribe to our channel http://bit.ly/AJSubscribe
#Aljazeeraenglish #News #climatechange #africa

entry.title: Lebanon port explosion: Victims‚Äô families demand a deeper inquiry

media:group.media:title: Lebanon port explosion: Victims‚Äô families demand a deeper inquiry
media:group.media:description:
Lebanon's caretaker prime minister has refused to cooperate with the investigation into the Beirut port explosion, which happened in August. Hassan Diab and three former cabinet ministers face charges of carelessness and neglect. Victims' families have welcomed the charges but say many more people need to be held to account. Al Jazeera‚Äôs Zeina Khodr reports from Beirut.

entry.title: What's the legacy of Bosnia's peace deal? | Inside Story

media:group.media:title: What's the legacy of Bosnia's peace deal? | Inside Story
media:group.media:description:
The Dayton Peace Accords ended the Bosnian war 25 years ago. The US brokered deal stopped an ethnic conflict that killed 100,000 people and displaced two million others. However, it divided Bosnia and Herzegovina into two entities, created a complex political system and entrenched divisions between Bosnian Muslims, Serbs and Croats. So can Bosnia and Herzegovina heal the widening fractures in society?
Presenter: Imran Khan
Guests: Aleksandar Brezar - Co-host, Sarajevo Calling podcast Amila Buturovic - Professor of Humanities, York University Toronto Gerald Knaus - Founding Chairman, European Stability Initiative
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#AlJazeeraEnglish #Bosnia # DaytonPeaceAccords

entry.title: ‚ÄòExternal source‚Äô causes oil tanker blast off Saudi Arabia

media:group.media:title: ‚ÄòExternal source‚Äô causes oil tanker blast off Saudi Arabia
media:group.media:description:
An oil tanker off Saudi Arabia‚Äôs port city of Jeddah has been hit by an unidentified ‚Äúexternal source‚Äù that caused a fire and an explosion, a shipping company said, suggesting another vessel has come under attack off the kingdom amid its years-long war in Yemen. In a statement on Monday, shipping company Hafnia said all 22 sailors on board the Singapore-flagged BW Rhine escaped without injury. The company warned it was possible some oil leaked out from the site of the blast. The ship‚Äôs crew put out the fire, the company said, adding that parts of the ship‚Äôs hull had been damaged. Al Jazeera's Andreas Krieg, an assistant professor at the defence studies department at King's College London, talks to Al Jazeera.

entry.title: Australia: 'Coral IVF' may help replenish Great Barrier Reef

media:group.media:title: Australia: 'Coral IVF' may help replenish Great Barrier Reef
media:group.media:description:
Researchers in Australia say they have developed a technique to grow and transplant new coral populations on the Great Barrier Reef. They say "Coral IVF" could help replenish one of the world‚Äôs most endangered ecosystems. Al Jazeera's Alexandra Byers reports.

entry.title: Child marriage rates surge in Sierra Leone

media:group.media:title: Child marriage rates surge in Sierra Leone
media:group.media:description:
The United Nation says child marriage rates have surged in Sierra Leone - because of the coronavirus pandemic.
The UN defines child marriage as a marriage of a girl or boy before the age of 18 and it says the number of girls getting married in Sierra Leone before that age dropped from 56 percent in 2006 to 39 percent 10 years later.
But when schools closed in March, child marriage rates surged.
It estimates that hardships resulting from COVID-19 will drive 13 million more girls to marry before the age of 18. Al Jazeera's Victoria Gatenby reports.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#AlJazeeraEnglish #SierraLeone #ChildBrides
